case_name: Haricharan Kurmi and Jogia Hajam v. State

facts.text: Two appellants Haricharan Kurmi and Jogia Hajam were charged along with four other persons Ram Bachan Ram, Joginder Singh, Ram Surat Choudhury and Achheylal Choudhury with offence under section 396 IPC.

anchor.surface_text: The two appellants Haricharan Kurmi and Jogia Hajam were charged along with four other persons with having committed an offence punishable under section 396 of the Indian Penal Code, in that during the night intervening the 24th and the 25th March, 1960, they committed dacoity in the house of Deokinandan Jaiswal, and during the course of the said dacoity, they committed the murder of Damyanti Devi, wife of the said Deokinandan Jaiswal. The names of the four other accused persons are Ram Bachan Ram, Joginder Singh, Ram Surat Choudhury and Achheylal Choudhury.

facts.text: Dacoity committed in house of Deokinandan Jaiswal during night intervening 24th and 25th March 1960, murder of Damyanti Devi during the dacoity.

anchor.surface_text: in that during the night intervening the 24th and the 25th March, 1960, they committed dacoity in the house of Deokinandan Jaiswal, and during the course of the said dacoity, they committed the murder of Damyanti Devi, wife of the said Deokinandan Jaiswal.

facts.text: Sessions Judge Muzaffarpur tried the case and found all six accused guilty under s.396 IPC, convicted and sentenced to imprisonment for life.

anchor.surface_text: The learned Sessions Judge, Muzaffarpur, who tried the case, found all the six accused persons guilty of the offence charged. He accordingly convicted them of the said offence and sentenced them to suffer imprisonment for life.

facts.text: Six accused appealed to Patna High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 554 and 556 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: This order of conviction and sentence was challenged by the said six accused persons by preferring appeals before ,the Patna High Court. The High Court has held that the learned trial Judge was right in convicting five of the six appellants

facts.text: Patna High Court judgment and order dated August 17, 1963 upheld conviction of five accused, acquitted Joginder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1963, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 554 and 556 of 1961.

facts.text: Patna High Court enhanced sentence of two appellants Haricharan Kurmi and Jogia Hajam to death.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the two appellants, however, the High Court took the view that the ends of justice required that the sentence of imprisonment for life imposed on them should be enhanced to that of death. Accordingly, the rule against them was made absolute and they have been ordered to be hanged.

facts.text: Supreme Court appeals by special leave: Criminal Appeals Nos. 208 and 209 of 1963, heard February 3, 1964.

anchor.surface_text: CRIMINAL APPELLATE JURISDICTION Criminal Appeals Nos. 208 and 209 of 1963. Appeals by special leave from the judgment and order dated August 17, 1963, of the Patna High Court in Criminal Appeals Nos. 554 and 556 of 1961.

facts.text: Deokinandan Jaiswal is wealthy businessman in village Dumarbana, police station Bairgania, district Muzaffarpur.

anchor.surface_text: Deokinandan Jaiswal is a fairly wealthy businessman and lives in village Dumarbana within the police station of Bairgania in the district of Muzaffarpur.

facts.text: On 24th March 1960, Jaiswal received Rs. 15,000 in currency notes from partner Nathan Mary in presence of minions Achheylal and Ram Bachan.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that on the 24th March, 1960, Jaiswal had received Rs. 15,000 in currency notes from his partner Nathan Mary in the presence of his minions Achheylal and Ram Bachan in fact, as the said amount was handed over to Jaiswal in the form of different currency notes, Ram Bachan and Achheylal were asked by him to count the said amount.

facts.text: Jaiswal added Rs. 2,000 from iron safe to Rs.15,000, put in bundles with slip containing signature and date, handed to wife Damyanti Devi who put in iron safe on first floor.

anchor.surface_text: The said amount was then put in different bundles by Jaiswal and to it was added another amount of Rs. 2,000 which he took out from his iron safe. The two bundles were then put together in a bigger bundle and to it was attached a slip containing his signature and date. According to Jaiswal, he handed over the amount of Rs. 17,000 thus put in two bundles to his wife Damyanti Devi, and in her turn, she put the said bundles into the iron safe which had been kept at the first floor of the house in the room adjoining the bed-room.

facts.text: On night of 24th March 1960, Jaiswal slept at Dharamshala due to late function, Damyanti Devi alone with child Mina (3.5 years) on first floor.

anchor.surface_text: During the days of these functions, Jaiswal used to return home by about 10 P.m., but on the night of the 24th March, 1960, the function went on late, and so, Jaiswal slept at the Dharamshala where the function took Place and did not return home. That is how Damvanti Devi was left alone in the house on the first floor and her only companion was her child Mina about 3 1/2 years old.

facts.text: On ground floor sleeping: Achheylal, Ram Bachan, Joginder Singh; Ram Surat on leave; Batahu cook in verandah.

anchor.surface_text: Apparently, Damyanti Devi retired to her bed-room with her little child and on the ground floor were sleeping three of the accused persons, Achheylal, Ram Bachan and Jogender Singh Ram Surat was on leave, so that out of the four servants employed by Jaiswal, three were sleeping on the premises. Batahu, the cook of the family, was sleeping in a verandah attched to the motor garage.

facts.text: Next day, Achheylal awakened Batahu, reported door open, went to first floor, found Damyanti Devi dead in pool of blood with cut injuries on neck, child asleep, bundles removed.

anchor.surface_text: Next day Batahu was awakened by Achheylal who reported to him that the door of the hall was open. Thereupon Achheylal and this witness went on the first floor and found that Damyanti Devi was lying dead in a pool of blood. There were cut injuries in her neck which had presumably caused severe bleeding. The little girl Mina was fast asleep. The bundles of currency notes had been removed by the miscreants who had committed the murder of Damyanti Devi.

facts.text: Appellants are co-villagers of Joginder Singh.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants are the co-villagers of Jogender Singh who was one of the accused persons.

facts.text: Achheylal and Ram Bachan served as minions under Jaiswal, Joginder Singh as sepoy, Ram Surat as personal servant.

anchor.surface_text: He has a house of his own. Achheylal and Ram Bachan served under him as minions. Jogender Sinch was Jaiswals sepoy and Ram Surat was his personal servant.

facts.text: Ram Surat, Achheylal and Ram Bachan made confessions, held voluntary and true by Sessions Judge and High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Ram Surat, Achheylal and Ram Bachan made confessions and it has been held by the High Court as well as the Learned Sessions Judge that the charge against them is proved. ... there is a concurrent finding of the courts below that the confession made by Ram Surat is voluntary and true.

facts.text: Bloodstained shirt recovered from Haricharan Kurmi, human blood traces; blood on his nails; blood stains in lane and house.

anchor.surface_text: Later, a shirt bearing blood stains was also found. ... the stains of blood on the shirt which was seized from the person of the appellant Haricharan were found to have traces of human blood. Similarly, the nails of Haricharans hands showed traces of blood

facts.text: Red-coloured check gamcha with blood-like stains (human blood) recovered from Jogia Hajam's house granary on 27th March 1960.

anchor.surface_text: In regard to the appellant Jogia, a red-coloured check gamcha which bore blood-like stains was recovered from the top of the earthern granary in his house at about 6 A.M. On 27th March, 1960. This gamcha was sent to the Chemical Analyser and it is reported to bear stains of human blood

facts.text: No direct evidence of offence commission, relied on confessions, recovery of stolen property and bloodstained clothes.

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution sought to prove its case against the six accused persons by relying on the confessions made by three of them, the recovery of the stolen property and discovery of bloodstained clothes in respect of the two appellants. There is no direct evidence to show how, when, and by whom the offence was committed.

facts.text: Supreme Court held evidence other than confessions insufficient to prove charge against appellants, acquitted them.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court was not right in confirming the conviction of the two appellants under s. 396 ,of the Indian Penal Code.

facts.text: Appellants arrested next day after offence on report by Jaiswal suspecting four employees and accomplices.

anchor.surface_text: The appellants were arrested the next day after the commission of the offence on the report made by Jaiswal that he suspected that the murder of his wife had been committed by his four employees and their accomplices, the two appellants before us.

facts.text: Investigation officer on 26th March 1960 at 3.30 pm found blood stains in lane near Jaiswal's godown and Haricharan's house.

anchor.surface_text: On the 26th March, 1960, at about 3.30 P.m. the investigation officer visited the lane between the southern wall of Jaiswals godown and the northern wall of the east- facing room of the appellant Haricharan and found some blood stains in the lane and on the walls of the grain godown.

facts.text: High Court discharged enhancement rule for Joginder Singh, Ram Bachan Ram, Ram Surat Choudhury, Achheylal Choudhury, confirmed life imprisonment.

anchor.surface_text: This rule has been discharged in regard to Joginder Singh who has been acquitted, as well as Ram Bachan Ram, Ram Surat Choudhury and Achheylal Choudhury, and the sentence of imprisonment for life imposed on them by he trial Judge has been confirmed.

issues.text: Whether the High Court has erred in law in treating the confession made by the accused Ram Surat Choudhury as substantive evidence against the appellants

anchor.surface_text: the short question of law which has been raised before us by Mr. Tatachari is that the High Court has erred in law in treating the confession made by the accused Ram Surat Choudhury as substantive evidence against them. This course adopted by the High Court

issues.text: Whether the approach adopted by the High Court is justified by the provisions of s. 30 of the Act as it has been consistently interpreted by judicial decisions

anchor.surface_text: That is how the only question which calls for our decision in the present appeals is the approach adopted by the High Court justified by the provisions of s. 30 of the Act as it has been consistently interpreted by judicial decisions for more than half a century ?

issues.text: What exactly is the scope and effect of taking into consideration a confession of a co-accused under section 30 of the Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: When s. 30 provides that the confession of a accused may be taken into consideration, what exactly is the scope and effect of such taking into consideration, is precisely the problem which has been raised in the present appeals.

issues.text: Whether the correctness of the observations made by this Court in Ram Prakash v. The State of Punjab supports the view taken by the Patna High Court

anchor.surface_text: These appeals were argued before a Division Bench of three learned Judges of this Court and it was brought to the notice of the said Bench that in dealing with the case of the appellants in the light of the confession made by a accused person, the High Court had relied on the observations made by this Court in Ram Prakash v. The State of Punjab.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the evidence from this point of view, we must first decide whether the evidence other than the confessional statements of the accused persons, particularly Ram Surat, on whose confession the High Court has substantially relied, is satisfactory and tends to prove the prosecution case.

arguments.claim: Confession under s.30 Evidence Act is not evidence as defined under s.3 Evidence Act

anchor.surface_text: It is clear that the confession mentioned in s. 30 is not evidence under s. 3 of the Act. Sec. 3 defines evidence as meaning and including- all statements which the Court permits or requires to be made before it by witnesses, in relation to matters of fact under inquiry

arguments.claim: Under s.30, court may take confession into consideration against co-accused but not obligatory and only after satisfying with other evidence

anchor.surface_text: Section 30 provides that when more persons than one are being tried jointly for the same offence, and a confession made by one of such persons affecting himself and some other of such persons is proved, the Court may take into consideration such confession as against such other person

arguments.claim: Proper approach: consider other evidence first; if satisfactory, use confession only to assure conclusion of guilt

anchor.surface_text: in dealing with a criminal case where the prosecution relies upon the confession of one accused person against another accused person, the proper approach to adopt is to consider the other evidence against such an accused person, and if the said evidence appears to be satisfactory

arguments.claim: Confession of co-accused weaker than accomplice testimony under s.133; accomplice is substantive but needs corroboration

arguments.claim: Ram Prakash case does not support treating co-accused confession like accomplice evidence requiring only material corroboration

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that in Ram Prakashs case, some observations have been made which do not seem to recognize the distinction between the evidence of an accomplice and the statements contained in the confession made by an accused person.

arguments.claim: Evidence other than confessions insufficient to prove guilt under s.396 IPC against appellants

arguments.claim: Suspicion however grave cannot take place of proof; presumption of innocence requires acquittal when evidence unsatisfactory

holdings.text: A confession of a co-accused under section 30 of the Evidence Act is not substantive evidence against the other accused but may be taken into consideration only after the other evidence is found satisfactory.

anchor.surface_text: Section 30 provides that when more persons than one are being tried jointly for the same offence, and a confession made by one of such persons affecting himself and some other of such persons is proved, the Court may take into consideration such confession as against such other person

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interprets s.30 textually: confession not under s.3 evidence definition; based on self-implication suggesting truth but discretionary; consistent with precedents like Bhuboni Sahu.

holdings.text: The proper approach is to first consider other evidence against the accused; if satisfactory to sustain charge, then turn to co-accused confession for assurance of guilt.

anchor.surface_text: in dealing with a criminal case where the prosecution relies upon the confession of one accused person against another accused person, the proper approach to adopt is to consider the other evidence against such an accused person, and if the said evidence appears to be satisfactory

holdings.reasoning_summary: Follows consistent judicial interpretation (e.g., Emperor v. Lalit Mohan, Bhuboni Sahu, Kashmira Singh); confession weak, not oath-bound, no cross-exam.

holdings.text: Confession under s.30 stands on different footing from accomplice testimony under s.133; accomplice evidence substantive but needs corroboration, confession weaker and not starting point.

anchor.surface_text: In appreciating the full effect of the provisions contained ,in s. 30, it may be useful to refer to the position of the evidence given by an accomplice under s. 133 of the Act. Section 133 provides that an accomplice shall be a competent witness against an accused person

holdings.reasoning_summary: Harmonious construction of ss.30,133,114(b); accomplice competent/substantive (s.3 evidence), confession not; judicial prudence rule.

holdings.text: Ram Prakash v. State of Punjab does not support treating co-accused confession as accomplice evidence requiring only material corroboration; High Court erred in relying on it.

anchor.surface_text: It, however, appears that in Ram Prakashs case, some observations have been made which do not seem to recognize the distinction between the evidence of an accomplice and the statements contained in the confession made by an accused person.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Distinguishes precedent: Ram Prakash had strong other evidence; observation on retracted confession value not equating to accomplice treatment.

holdings.text: Evidence other than confessional statements (blood stains on clothes, nails, lane) is entirely insufficient to prove prosecution case under s.396 IPC against appellants.

anchor.surface_text: Considering the evidence from this point of view, we must first decide whether the evidence other than the confessional statements of the accused persons, particularly Ram Surat, on whose confession the High Court has substantially relied, is satisfactory and tends to prove

holdings.reasoning_summary: Applies correct approach: blood stains origin undetermined, too small/old, no connection to offence time/victim; recoveries suspicious.

holdings.text: High Court not right in confirming conviction of appellants under s.396 IPC; acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: We are, therefore, satisfied that the High Court was not right in confirming the conviction of the two appellants under s. 396 ,of the Indian Penal Code.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Other evidence unsatisfactory; cannot use confession as substantive; presumption of innocence, grave suspicion no substitute for proof.

holdings.text: Suspicion however grave cannot take place of proof; presumption of innocence compels acquittal when other evidence wholly unsatisfactory.
holdings.reasoning_summary: Principle of criminal jurisprudence; applies to facts where confession detailed but other evidence fails.
